references.A10FEL01USGP: Feldman, C. R., and R. F. Hoyer. 2010. A new species of snake in the genus Contia (Squamata: Colubridae) from California and Oregon. Copeia 2010: 254-267.
references.W12NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2012. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.
references.B02STJ01USGP: St. John, A. D. 2002. Reptiles of the Northwest: Alaska to California; Rockies to the Coast. Lone Pine Publishing. Alberta, Canada.
references.B03STE01USGP: Stebbins, R.C. 2003. A field guide to western reptiles and amphibians.  Third Edition. Houghton Mifflin, Boston.
references.R07HAM01USGP: Hammerson, G.A. 2007. Contia tenuis. In: IUCN 2012. IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2012.2. <www.iucnredlist.org>. January 2013.
references.A06HOY01USGP: Hoyer, R.F.,R. P. O'Donnell, R.T. Mason. 2006.  CURRENT DISTRIBUTION AND STATUS OF SHARP-TAILED SNAKES (CONTIA TENUIS) IN OREGON. Northwestern Naturalist 87(3):195-202.

habitat_description:
The sharp-tailed snake occurs from central and northern California and also further north into Oregon and neighboring locations of Washington. Populations have also been reported at the southern end of Vancouver Island and the nearby Gulf Islands of British Columbia.  This species can be found along the Coast Ranges; south into San Luis Obispo County, Sierra Nevada south to Tulare County; Willamette Valley, Oregon; the east side of the Cascades in Washington. The elevational range of this species extends from sea level to approximately 2010 meters (Feldman and Hoyer 2010; Stebbins 2003; St. John 2002).

This species inhabits a wide variety of environments. From riparian situations to savanna and various woodland types. It occurs in bare rock, talus, scree, forest woodland, grassland, shrubland, chaparral, conifer woodland, and oak woodland (Natureserve.org). Stebbins (2003) has reported the habitats preferred by this snake include moist situations in pastures, meadows, oak woodlands, and along the edges of hardwood and coniferous forests. Weaver (2004), as reported by Natureserve.org, documented occurrences of this species in shrubby rabbitbrush-sagebrush.


NW	-Conifer forests, oak woodland, and moist situations in pastures.
SW	-Grassland, shrubland, and chaparral, and along riparian zones.
